elements.content: The chemistry of metal phosphonates has been progressing fast with the addition of new materials that possess novel structural features and new properties, occasionally in a cooperative manner. In this paper, we report a new family of functional lanthanide-carboxyphosphonate materials. Specifically, the lanthanide is La, Ce, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, or Dy and the carboxyphosphonate ligand is 2-hydroxyphosphonoacetic acid (H3HPA). All reported LnHPA compounds, Ln3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4·xH2O (x = 15–16), crystallize in the orthorhombic system. Two types of structures were isolated: series I and II polymorphs. For both series, the three-dimensional (3D) open frameworks result from the linkage of similar organo-inorganic layers, in the ac-plane, by central lanthanide cations, which yield trimeric units also found in other metal-HPA hybrids. Large oval-shaped 1D channels are formed by the spatial separation of the layers along the b-axis and filled with lattice water molecules. LnHPA materials undergo remarkable crystalline-to-amorphous-to crystalline transformations upon dehydration and rehydration cycles, as confirmed by thermodiffraction and NMR spectroscopy. The highest proton conductivity was observed for GdHPA (series II), 3.2 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 98% RH and T = 21 °C. The dehydration–rehydration chemistry was also followed by photoluminescence spectroscopy. It was shown that loss and reuptake of water molecules are accompanied by clear changes in the photoluminescence spectra and lifetimes of the Eu analog (series II). Our present results reveal a wide family of well-characterized, multifunctional lanthanide-based phosphonate 3D-structured metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that show reversible crystalline-to-amorphous-to-crystalline transformations and, at the same time, exhibit high proton conductivity.

elements.content: The field of metal–organic framework (MOF) materials has skyrocketed during the last 10 years, principally because of two reasons: (a) the increasing appearance of a milieu of new structural motifs, and (b) the enormous functionality of such materials. In particular, lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are presently receiving growing attention, because of their potential applications in fields such as gas adsorption, magnetism, and catalysis, and especially for their photoluminescence properties. Ln-MOFs are very promising as multifunctional luminescent materials, because both the inorganic and organic moieties can provide suitable platforms to generate luminescence. Moreover, metal–ligand charge transfer and/or the presence of guest molecules within porous MOFs can potentially generate and tailor the luminescence properties. Multifunctional Ln-MOFs are usually based on, but not restricted to, a combination of photoluminescence and some other additional properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of metal-organic framework (MOF) materials has skyrocketed during the last 10 years, principally because of two reasons: (a) the increasing appearance of a milieu of new structural motifs, and (b) the enormous functionality of such materials. In particular, lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are presently receiving growing attention, because of their potential applications in fields such as gas adsorption, magnetism, and catalysis, and especially for their photoluminescence properties. Ln-MOFs are very promising as multifunctional luminescent materials, because both the inorganic and organic moieties can provide suitable platforms to generate luminescence. Moreover, metal-ligand charge transfer and/or the presence of guest molecules within porous MOFs can potentially generate and tailor the luminescence properties. Multifunctional Ln-MOFs are usually based on, but not restricted to, a combination of photoluminescence and some other additional properties.

elements.content: The adjustable structures and properties of MOFs, together with the rich coordination chemistry and functionality of the rare-earth ions, should constitute an important advantage over other candidate classes for a variety of solid-state applications such as chemo-sensory materials, light-emitting materials, or proton conductors. A multitude of organic linkers, such as carboxylates, phosphonates, or sulfonates, have been utilized to construct lanthanide MOFs. Multichelate phosphonate ligands are “alternative” organic linkers (to the widespread polycarboxylates) and allow access to a variety of thermally and chemically stable MOFs. Such architectures have also been reported for Ln-MOFs. However, control over the dimensionality of phosphonate-based Ln-MOFs still remains an unconquered challenge.

Multichelate phosphonate ligands are "alternative" organic linkers (to the widespread polycarboxylates) and allow access to a variety of thermally and chemically stable MOFs. elements.content: Recently, phosphonoacetic acid has been employed in synthetic efforts, giving rise to a series of isostructural two-dimensional (2D) layered lanthanide phosphonates, by employing hydrothermal conditions and lanthanide nitrates as the Ln source. By using a closely related inexpensive ligand, 2-hydroxyphosphonoacetic acid (H3HPA), we have recently synthesized 2D and 3D Ca-MOFs. The main structural feature of these compounds is that the frameworks are constructed from trimeric Ca-HPA-Ca-HPA-Ca secondary building units (SBUs) interconnected through phosphonate/carboxylate moeties. The trimeric SBU could even be isolated as a “stand-alone” species at neutral pH. Furthermore, Cd2+ derivatives were found to follow a close pattern of crystallization, indicating that this trimeric unit may be a common structural “brick” of a variety of 2D and 3D metal frameworks, within a wide range of ionic radii. Previous studies carried out with divalent metal phosphonoacetates showed that synthesis at room temperature favors the formation of solids of low dimensionality, 1D or 2D. The preparation of solids with tridimensional frameworks usually requires hydrothermal/solvothermal conditions.

elements.content: Within the field of metal phosphonates, elegant efforts have been put forth for access to suitable proton-conducting materials. For a material to be proton-conductive, it needs to contain acidic protons and must have an appropriate framework that facilitates charge transport. In the case of metal phosphonates, the role of acidic groups is played by the phosphonic acid (or partially protonated phosphonate) groups. In such crystalline structural architectures, highly ordered phosphonate groups in close proximity with lattice water molecules create pathways that could yield proton conductors.

In the case of metal phosphonates, the role of acidic groups is played by the phosphonic acid (or partially protonated phosphonate) groups. In such crystalline structural architectures, highly ordered phosphonate groups in close proximity with lattice water molecules create pathways that could yield proton conductors.

elements.content: In the present work, we report two series of lanthanide open-framework hybrids based on H3HPA. These materials were obtained by slow crystallization at ambient conditions from very acidic aqueous solutions. They possess high water content (both Ln-coordinated and in the lattice), they exhibit the aforementioned trimeric SBU structural feature, and importantly, they form water-filled 1D channels. The most remarkable attributes of these hybrids are high proton conductivity, water-content-dependent photoluminescence and remarkable crystalline-to-amorphous-to-crystalline transformations.

elements.content: All starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used as-received. Deionized (DI) water was used for all syntheses. The lanthanide (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) nitrate hexahydrate salts (99.5%), were from Alfa, USA. Sodium alginate was from Aldrich, USA. H3HPA (60% aqueous solution) was from Biolabs, UK. The pH meter used was a wTw pH315i setup, equipped with a SeTix 41 electrode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were measured on a Perkin–Elmer Model 240 analyzer. Infrared spectra were collected in a FTIR Nicolet 5DXC spectrometer. All spectra were recorded in the 4000–400 cm–1 range at 4 cm–1 resolution, and 50 scans were accumulated. In situ surface infrared spectra for one sample, was collected by diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), using a Varian 3100 FTIR spectrometer. A Harrick Scientific Praying Mantis equipped with a high-temperature reaction chamber was mounted inside the spectrometer. Measurements were carried out between room temperature and 190 °C. The background spectrum was recorded with KBr purged with a 50 mL min–1 He flow. The DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species were measured under a He flow in the 4000–400 cm–1 interval with a resolution of 4 cm–1, collected by adding 124 scans. SEM images were collected on an SEM system (LEO VP-35 FEM).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All starting materials were obtained from commercial sources and used as-received. Deionized (DI) water was used for all syntheses. The lanthanide (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) nitrate hexahydrate salts (99.5%), were from Alfa, USA. Sodium alginate was from Aldrich, USA. H3HPA (60% aqueous solution) was from Biolabs, UK. The pH meter used was a wTw pH315i setup, equipped with a SeTix 41 electrode. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were measured on a Perkin-Elmer Model 240 analyzer. Infrared spectra were collected in a FTIR Nicolet 5DXC spectrometer. All spectra were recorded in the 4000-400 cm-1 range at 4 cm-1 resolution, and 50 scans were accumulated. In situ surface infrared spectra for one sample, was collected by diffuse-reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), using a Varian 3100 FTIR spectrometer. A Harrick Scientific Praying Mantis equipped with a high-temperature reaction chamber was mounted inside the spectrometer. Measurements were carried out between room temperature and 190 °C. The background spectrum was recorded with KBr purged with a 50 mL min-1 He flow. The DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species were measured under a He flow in the 4000-400 cm-1 interval with a resolution of 4 cm-1, collected by adding 124 scans. SEM images were collected on an SEM system (LEO VP-35 FEM).

elements.content: For the syntheses in gels, the following stock solutions were prepared. By using the concentrated H3HPA starting solution, a more-dilute 0.133 M stock solution was made. Fifteen milliliters (15 mL) of this solution contains 0.3 mmol of H3HPA. Using the solid lanthanide nitrates, 0.1 M stock solutions were prepared in DI water. In a glass beaker, 1 g of sodium alginate was dissolved in ∼100 mL of DI water, thus generating a 1% w/v solution. Four milliliters (4 mL) of the above alginate stock solution are transferred into 25-mL glass vials. Then, with a Pasteur pipet, 2 mL (0.2 mmol) of the above lanthanide stock solutions were added. Upon addition of the lanthanide solution, immediate gel formation was observed. The forming gel was left undisturbed for at least 9 h to ensure maximum exchange of Ln3+ ions for Na+ ions. Subsequently, the excess liquid was decanted, the gel was washed several times with DI water, and was then ready for the next step.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Lanthanide-HPA Materials

Synthesis of Lanthanide-Containing Alginate Gels

For the syntheses in gels, the following stock solutions were prepared. By using the concentrated H3HPA starting solution, a more-dilute 0.133 M stock solution was made. Fifteen milliliters (15 mL) of this solution contains 0.3 mmol of H3HPA. Using the solid lanthanide nitrates, 0.1 M stock solutions were prepared in DI water. In a glass beaker, 1 g of sodium alginate was dissolved in ~100 mL of DI water, thus generating a 1% w/v solution. Four milliliters (4 mL) of the above alginate stock solution are transferred into 25-mL glass vials. Then, with a Pasteur pipet, 2 mL (0.2 mmol) of the above lanthanide stock solutions were added. Upon addition of the lanthanide solution, immediate gel formation was observed. The forming gel was left undisturbed for at least 9 h to ensure maximum exchange of Ln3+ ions for Na+ ions. Subsequently, the excess liquid was decanted, the gel was washed several times with DI water, and was then ready for the next step.

elements.content: The method described below was applied for the following lanthanides: Ce, Pr, Sm, Gd, Tb, and Dy, The syntheses were performed in five different pH values: 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0. A volume of 15 mL of the above-described H3HPA stock solution (0.2 mmol in H3HPA) was pre-acidified with HCl to the desired pH value and was then added to the beaker containing the Ln-containing alginate gel, using a Pasteur pipet. In this way, the gel is completely immersed in liquid. The vial containing the gel is covered and left undisturbed to stand for several days. Depending on the lanthanide used, crystals may form after 2 days, or longer. The formed crystals are left to grow until no further crystal growth can be detected by the naked eye. We have observed that, depending on the Ln:H3HPA system, crystals may form on the surface of the gel, embedded inside the gel, or even at the bottom of the vial. After the crystallization reaction is complete, the gel is removed from the vial with a pair of small tongues and placed on filter paper on a vacuum filtration system. Usually, mechanical shaking in combination with washing with DI water is sufficient to completely dislodge the crystals from the gel. The isolated crystals are further washed with DI water and finally air-dried. All products are examined under an optical microscope to ensure that no contamination from the gel material is present. Common reaction yields range from 10% to 20%.
elements.clean_text:
Gel-Assisted Preparation of Ln-HPA Materials

The method described below was applied for the following lanthanides: Ce, Pr, Sm, Gd, Tb, and Dy, The syntheses were performed in five different pH values: 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0. A volume of 15 mL of the above-described H3HPA stock solution (0.2 mmol in H3HPA) was pre-acidified with HCl to the desired pH value and was then added to the beaker containing the Ln-containing alginate gel, using a Pasteur pipet. In this way, the gel is completely immersed in liquid. The vial containing the gel is covered and left undisturbed to stand for several days. Depending on the lanthanide used, crystals may form after 2 days, or longer. The formed crystals are left to grow until no further crystal growth can be detected by the naked eye. We have observed that, depending on the Ln:H3HPA system, crystals may form on the surface of the gel, embedded inside the gel, or even at the bottom of the vial. After the crystallization reaction is complete, the gel is removed from the vial with a pair of small tongues and placed on filter paper on a vacuum filtration system. Usually, mechanical shaking in combination with washing with DI water is sufficient to completely dislodge the crystals from the gel. The isolated crystals are further washed with DI water and finally air-dried. All products are examined under an optical microscope to ensure that no contamination from the gel material is present. Common reaction yields range from 10% to 20%.

elements.content: For the bulk syntheses, preparation of 0.4 M H3HPA and 0.4 M Ln nitrate was necessary. Room-temperature reactions between the lanthanide of choice (see above) and H3HPA were carried out in conventional glassware. Four different Ln:H3HPA molar ratios were tested: 1:1, 1:2, 1:3, and 1:5. Also, the final reaction volumes were varied (20, 40, 60, and 80 mL). In a glass beaker containing the desired volume of DI water (see above), 0.5 mL (0.2 mmol) of the 0.4 M Ln stock solution was placed. Then, the desired volume of the 0.4 M H3HPA stock solution was added. For example, if the desired Ln:H3HPA molar ratio is 1:1, then 0.5 mL of the Ln stock solution is added. The pH value was adjusted to ∼1.0 using HCl. The beaker is then covered with parafilm, holes are punctured for slow water evaporation, and the reaction mixture is left undisturbed for several days. It is frequently monitored for crystal formation. When no further crystal growth is noted, the formed microcrystalline solids (almost invariably polycrystalline aggregates in spherical form) are isolated by filtration, washed with DI water, and air-dried. Three solid solutionsEu0.95Tb0.05HPA, Eu0.9Tb0.1HPA and Gd0.95Tb0.05HPAwere prepared following the above-described procedure and using a Ln:H3HPA overall molar ratio of 1:1. The final reaction volume was 40 mL, and the solution pH was in the range of 0.80–1.50 (depending on individual synthesis). Low pH values were chosen in order to avoid quick precipitation and allow the formation of crystalline products. Routinely, yields of ∼50% are noted, based on the metal. FT-IR spectra of all materials are essentially identical. As an example, the main bands in the FT-IR spectrum (cm–1) of Ln-HPA are as follows: 3345 (br), 3203 (br), 2652 (w), 2626 (sh), 1577 (s), 1423 (m), 1371 (sh), 1273 (w), 1165 (sh), 1160 (s), 979 (m), 821 (w). Some representative syntheses were also tried under hydrothermal conditions (Ln = La, Ce, 120 °C, pH 1.0, 1.5, 2.0) and the resulting products were the same as those from the RT syntheses.
elements.clean_text:

For the bulk syntheses, preparation of 0.4 M H3HPA and 0.4 M Ln nitrate was necessary. Room-temperature reactions between the lanthanide of choice (see above) and H3HPA were carried out in conventional glassware. Four different Ln:H3HPA molar ratios were tested: 1:1, 1:2, 1:3, and 1:5. Also, the final reaction volumes were varied (20, 40, 60, and 80 mL). In a glass beaker containing the desired volume of DI water (see above), 0.5 mL (0.2 mmol) of the 0.4 M Ln stock solution was placed. Then, the desired volume of the 0.4 M H3HPA stock solution was added. For example, if the desired Ln:H3HPA molar ratio is 1:1, then 0.5 mL of the Ln stock solution is added. The pH value was adjusted to ~1.0 using HCl. The beaker is then covered with parafilm, holes are punctured for slow water evaporation, and the reaction mixture is left undisturbed for several days. It is frequently monitored for crystal formation. When no further crystal growth is noted, the formed microcrystalline solids (almost invariably polycrystalline aggregates in spherical form) are isolated by filtration, washed with DI water, and air-dried. Three solid solutionsEu0.95Tb0.05HPA, Eu0.9Tb0.1HPA and Gd0.95Tb0.05HPAwere prepared following the above-described procedure and using a Ln:H3HPA overall molar ratio of 1:1. The final reaction volume was 40 mL, and the solution pH was in the range of 0.80-1.50 (depending on individual synthesis). Low pH values were chosen in order to avoid quick precipitation and allow the formation of crystalline products. Routinely, yields of ~50% are noted, based on the metal. FT-IR spectra of all materials are essentially identical. elements.content: Differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on an SDT-Q600 analyzer from TA Instruments. Initially, the temperature was varied from RT to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Measurements were carried out on a sample in an open platinum crucible under a flow of air. A second set of measurements were carried out under N2 flow, saturated with water at 25 °C, to characterize the release and uptake of water by La 3 (H 0.75 O 3 PCHOHCOO) 4 ·16H 2 O (body-centered structure, see below (LaHPA-I)) and Gd 3 (H 0.75 O 3 PCHOHCOO) 4 ·16H 2 O (primitive structure; see below (GdHPA-II)).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on an SDT-Q600 analyzer from TA Instruments. Initially, the temperature was varied from RT to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Measurements were carried out on a sample in an open platinum crucible under a flow of air. A second set of measurements were carried out under N2 flow, saturated with water at 25 °C, to characterize the release and uptake of water by La  3  (H  0.75  O  3  PCHOHCOO)  4  ⋅16H  2  O (body-centered structure, see below (LaHPA-I)) and Gd  3  (H  0.75  O  3  PCHOHCOO)  4  ⋅16H  2  O (primitive structure; see below (GdHPA-II)).

elements.content: Thermodiffractometric studies were carried out for both polymorphic phases of LaHPA with the sample loaded in an Anton Paar HTK 1200N chamber under static air. Data were collected at 30, 40, 60, 80, and 90 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min–1 and a delay time of 10 min to ensure thermal stabilization. The data acquisition range was 4°–60° (2θ) with a step size of 0.017° and an equivalent counting time of 118 s/step. A second study for both polymorphs was carried out with the same camera, at room temperature, but under vacuum (final pressure ∼2.5 × 10–4 bar) and at different times (from 1 h to 4 h). The data range was 4°–50° (2θ), with a step size of 0.033° and an equivalent counting time of 50 s/step.

The data range was 4°-50° (2θ), with a step size of 0.033° and an equivalent counting time of 50 s/step.

elements.content: 31P and 1H MAS (magic angle spinning) NMR spectra were recorded at 161.98 and 400.13 MHz, respectively, on a Bruker Avance 400 spectrometer. The external magnetic field was 9.4 T. All measurements were carried out at 20 °C and the samples were spun around the magic angle (54°44′ with respect to the magnetic field) at spinning rates between 10 kHz and 12 kHz. The 31P MAS NMR spectra were obtained with two experimental sequences (single pulse and proton decoupling) after a π/2 excitations of 4 μs, and intervals between successive accumulations of 30 s. 1H MAS NMR spectra were obtained with a single pulse sequence of 6-μs duration and 5 s of recycle delay. The 31P chemical shift values are given relative to a 85% H3PO4 aqueous solutions and those of 1H relative to (CH3)4Si. The deconvolution of 31P MAS NMR spectra was carried out using the DMFIT program, so that the different components and their contributions could be revealed.

elements.content: Laboratory powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a PANanalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer in a Bragg–Brentano reflection configuration by using a Ge(111) primary monochromator (Cu Kα1) and the X’Celerator detector. PXRD patterns were autoindexed using the DICVOL06 program, and the space groups were derived from the observed systematic extinctions. To minimize the preferred orientation effects, samples of CeHPA and PrHPA were mixed with a small amount (5%–10% in weight) of Cab-o-Sil M-5 (from Fluka), as previously reported. The PXRD patterns were recorded between 4° and 100° (2θ), with a 0.017° step size and an equivalent counting time of ∼400 s/step.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination and Refinement

Laboratory powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a PANanalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer in a Bragg-Brentano reflection configuration by using a Ge(111) primary monochromator (Cu Kα1) and the X'Celerator detector. PXRD patterns were autoindexed using the DICVOL06 program, and the space groups were derived from the observed systematic extinctions. To minimize the preferred orientation effects, samples of CeHPA and PrHPA were mixed with a small amount (5%-10% in weight) of Cab-o-Sil M-5 (from Fluka), as previously reported. The PXRD patterns were recorded between 4° and 100° (2θ), with a 0.017° step size and an equivalent counting time of ~400 s/step.

elements.content: All compounds crystallize as polycrystalline solids and only for CeHPA-I and GdHPA-II small single crystals (microcrystals) were isolated. Data for GdHPA-II were collected on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Dual diffractometer equipped with an EOS CCD detector at −173(2) °C with Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å), making omega scans when collecting the data, with a 1.0° scan width and 80 s per frame exposure time. Cell refinement and data reduction were performed with CrysAlisPro. The structure was solved by direct methods revealing the positions of all non-hydrogen atoms. These atoms were refined on F 2 via a full-matrix least-squares procedure, using anisotropic displacement parameters. The H-atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. Corrections for absorption were performed using the multiscan facilities implemented in CrysAlisPro. The contribution of the disordered solvent molecules to the overall intensity data of all structures were eliminated using the SQUEEZE method in PLATON.

elements.content: A CeHPA-I microcrystal was prepared for measurement under inert conditions immersed in perfluoropolyether protecting oil. It was mounted on a MiTeGen Micromount and then used for data collection. Data were collected (λ = 0.73780, −173 °C) at the ESRF synchrotron BM16 beamline (Grenoble, France). The data were processed with APEX2 and corrected for absorption using SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods, revealing the position of all non-hydrogen atoms, except those corresponding to some water molecules. The localized atoms were refined on F 2 by a full-matrix least-squares procedure, using anisotropic displacement parameters; however, the refinement did not converge due to poor quality of the single microcrystals and the structural disorder. Thus, the obtained partial structure was used as initial model for a Rietveld refinement using laboratory PXRD. The used 2θ range for all refinements was 14°–100° (2θ), to avoid the strong effects of asymmetry and preferred orientation at very low angles.

elements.content: The missing atoms were localized by difference of Fourier maps. The structures were refined by the Rietveld method, using the program GSAS and the graphic interface EXPGUI. To maintain chemically reasonable geometries for the carbon chain, as well as phosphonate and carboxylate groups, the following soft constraints were established: /PO3C1 tetrahedron/P–O [1.53(1) Å], P–C1 [1.80(1) Å], O···O [2.55(2) Å], O···C1 [2.73(2) Å], /C1OH–C2OO group/C1–C2 [1.50(1) Å], C2-Ocarb [1.23(1) Å], C1–OH [1.40(1) Å], P···OH [2.68(2) Å], C2–OH [2.40(2) Å], Ocarb···Ocarb [2.21(2) Å], and C1···Ocarb [2.36(2) Å]. Those LnIII–O bond distances deviating by more than the 15% from the reported Shannon average values were also constrained [2.60(5) Å] during the refinement. Water molecules for CeHPA-I and TbHPA-II were located in difference Fourier maps and included in the refinements. No attempts to locate the H atoms were carried out due to the limited quality of the PXRD data. The final weight factor for the constraints was 10. The atomic displacement parameters were fixed (U iso = 0.01 Å3) and not refined for the LaHPA derivatives. For CeHPA-I, only a commom atomic displacement parameter was refined for all atoms. For TbHPA-II, three atomic displacement parameters were isotropically refined, one for Ln atoms, another for both phosphorus atoms, and a third value for the remaining atoms. Rietveld plots for LaHPA-I, LaHPA-II, CeHPA-I, and TbHPA-II are given in the . The final structural model obtained for CeHPA-I (from the PXRD data) and GdHPA-II (from single-crystal data) were used as starting model for the structural refinement of the remaining members of the both series. Crystallographic data for LaHPA-I, LaHPA-II, CeHPA-I, and GdHPA-II are presented in Table , along with their corresponding CCDC reference codes. The crystallographic data for the remaining LnHPA compounds are given in .

The nitrogen sorption–desorption isotherms were measured in a Micromeritic ASAP 2020 apparatus. The samples were degassed under high vacuum and the isotherms, obtained at −196 °C, were analyzed by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Carbon dioxide sorption isotherms were measured in a Micromeritic ASAP 2020 apparatus. The samples were degassed at room temperature for several hours and the isotherms obtained at 0 °C were analyzed by the Dubinin–Radushkevich (DR) method.

Textural Characterization

Carbon dioxide sorption isotherms were measured in a Micromeritic ASAP 2020 apparatus. The samples were degassed at room temperature for several hours and the isotherms obtained at 0 °C were analyzed by the Dubinin-Radushkevich (DR) method.

elements.content: Electrical characterization for LaHPA-I and GdHPA-II was carried out on cylindrical pellets (diameter of ∼10 mm and thickness of ∼1 mm) obtained by pressing ∼0.2 g of sample at 1000 MPa, for 2 min. The pellets were pressed between porous C electrodes (Sigracet, GDL 10 BB, no Pt). Impedance spectroscopy data were collected using a HP4284A impedance analyzer over the frequency range from 20 Hz to 1 MHz with an applied voltage of 0.2 V. Electrical measurements were taken from 21 to 11 °C in 2 °C steps under variable relative humidities (% RH), which were obtained by a continuous flow of water-saturated air through the cell. The air was bubbled in a thermostatic Julabo F32 water bath at different temperatures, with a precision of 0.1 °C. The pellet was equilibrated at a given RH for 90 min to ensure a fixed water content of the sample. A small temperature range, 10 °C, has been selected in order to have fixed water content for the studied samples and to have an approximately constant RH. All measurements were electronically controlled by the winDETA package of programs.

elements.content: Steady-state photoluminescence measurements were recorded in a Photon Technology International (PTI) 220B spectrofluorimeter having a Xe arc lamp light excitation and Czerny-Turner monochromator, coupled to a photomultiplier. Time-resolved measurements were performed using a PTI spectrofluorimeter with a Xe–Hg flash lamp (2 μs/pulse half) as excitation pulse and a Czerny–Turner monochromator. The solid samples were pressed between two windows Suprasil quartz cuvettes with a path length of 0.01 mm and placed at a 45° angle to both the excitation and emission monochromators. All measurements were carried out at room temperature.

elements.content: Initial synthetic attempts were focused on the crystal growth of LnHPA products in alginate gels. This methodology has been successful for a variety of metal phosphonate compounds. This approach takes advantage of initial lanthanide coordination by the carboxylate groups within the alginate hydrogel. Subsequently, the added H3HPA ligand coordinates to the Ln center, thus creating the initial nuclei that grow within days.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Initial synthetic attempts were focused on the crystal growth of LnHPA products in alginate gels. This methodology has been successful for a variety of metal phosphonate compounds. This approach takes advantage of initial lanthanide coordination by the carboxylate groups within the alginate hydrogel. Subsequently, the added H3HPA ligand coordinates to the Ln center, thus creating the initial nuclei that grow within days.

elements.content: In room-temperature syntheses, many factors can be easily controlled, such as pH and Ln:HPA ratio. The former was varied from 0.80 to 1.50 and the latter from 1:1 to 1:5 with similar results. The effect of pH on the morphology of the end materials was studied by electron microscopy, and the results are shown in Figure . It appears that the lower the synthesis pH, the larger the platelike crystals that form the aggregates. Macroscopically, the aggregates take a semispherical shape. However, upon closer examination (see, for example, the CeHPA case at pH 0.84), the aggregates are composed of smaller, platelike crystals.

elements.content: All reported compounds, Ln3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4·xH2O (Ln = La, Ce, Sm, Pr, Gd, Eu, Tb, Dy; x = 15–16) crystallize in the orthorhombic system. Two types of structures were isolated, hereafter identified as series I and II polymorphs. Series I compounds crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric structure (e.g,. Iba2), whereas series II samples crystallize in a centrosymmetric structure (e.g., Pcan). In addition to the structural analysis, the change in the crystal symmetry is qualitatively evidenced upon comparing the XRD patterns (see Figure ), by the presence of a several small intensity peaks corresponding to reflections forbidden in the body-centered cell. It must be emphasized that, for the lanthanum derivative, the polymorphic phase LaHPA-I was obtained for pH values lower than 0.8, whereas LaHPA-II was prepared at pH values higher than 1.0. Syntheses at intermediate pH values led to a mixture of phases (see Figure ).

Structural Study

Two types of structures were isolated, hereafter identified as series I and II polymorphs. Series I compounds crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric structure (e.g,. Iba2), whereas series II samples crystallize in a centrosymmetric structure (e.g., Pcan). In addition to the structural analysis, the change in the crystal symmetry is qualitatively evidenced upon comparing the XRD patterns (see Figure ), by the presence of a several small intensity peaks corresponding to reflections forbidden in the body-centered cell. It must be emphasized that, for the lanthanum derivative, the polymorphic phase LaHPA-I was obtained for pH values lower than 0.8, whereas LaHPA-II was prepared at pH values higher than 1.0. Syntheses at intermediate pH values led to a mixture of phases (see Figure ).

elements.content: The unit-cell volumes range between 4020.3(3) Å3 (LaHPA-I) and 3698.4(4) Å3 (DyHPA-II) (see ). Data reported in indicate that the b-axis, defining the direction of the layer packing, shrinks slightly more than the a- and c-axes. Figure shows that, for both series, the cell volume decreases linearly with the ionic radius (average CN = 8) but with different slopes. As discussed below, these two series contains different trimeric units, which justifies the slightly different slopes. According to Figure , series I (Ln = La, Ce, and Pr) materials would have unit-cell volumes bigger than those of series II. The intersection point, r ≈ 1.11 Å, would correspond to Nd3+. However, heavier lanthanides hybrids, those with r < 1.11 Å, crystallize only in series II type structures, under the investigated experimental conditions.

elements.content: Suitable single (micro)crystals of CeHPA-I and GdHPA-II were obtained. However, only the crystal structure of GdHPA-II could be successfully refined. The content of the asymmetric unit for GdHPA-II is given in Figure . This part contains two lanthanide atoms (one in special position (Gd1) and a second one in a general position (Gd2)), two H x HPA ligands (P1 and P2), and four Gd-bound water molecules. In addition, the unit cell contains four disordered water molecules, as determined in the chemical analysis that was modeled with the SQUEEZE program in PLATON and treated as an unlocalized contribution to the overall scattering. It must be underlined that the layer connectivity observed for series II, represented by GdHPA-II, is maintained in series I, represented by CeHPA-I (see below), which results in similar frameworks, despite their different crystal symmetries.

elements.content: The structures of these compounds can be described as being composed of organic–inorganic layers in the ac-plane connected by lanthanide cations along the b-axis. Remarkably, the layer atomic arrangement in the ac-plane is the same in both series (see ), despite the different crystal symmetries. These layers contain infinite chains, running along the a-axis, formed by two types of chelating rings. These rings are 6-membered, Ln2–O–C–C–P1–O–Ln2 and 5-membered, Ln2–O–C–C–O–Ln2 (see ). These chains are linked together along the c-axis just by the P1–O1–Ln2 linkage developing the organic–inorganic layers. This layer-binding mode resembles that found in M(II)HPA compounds and Ln(III)-oxalatocarboxyphosphonates. Thus, the 3D framework may be envisaged as a layered structure formed by {Ln2(P1)}+ units (see ), and pillared along the b-axis by Ln1{P2}2 units, see Figure , to give the open frameworks shown in Figure .

elements.content: For CeHPA-I, the overall octa-coordination around Ln(1) is maintained. However, the different arrangement of the water molecules bound to interlayer-Ln1 in both series must be emphasized. Thus, for series II, the four waters of the Ln1 point outward in opposite directions, toward the phosphonate groups P2. Meanwhile, for series I, they are situated between the two P2 groups (see Figure ). For both series, intralayer-Ln2 is 9-coordinated. Seven coordination positions are provided by three P1 ligands and one P2 ligand. Two P1 ligands chelate Ln2 through pairs of oxygen atoms from either the phosphonate and the carboxylate groups [O2, O5] or the hydroxyl and carboxylate groups [O4, O6]. A third P1 ligand binds to Ln2 by only one oxygen atom from the phosphonate group, [O1] (see ). Two more sites are occupied by a pair of oxygen atoms from the hydroxyl [O10] and the carboxylate [O11] groups of a P2 ligand than joins the layers along the b-axis. The coordination is completed by two water molecules Ow1 and Ow4. This arrangement results in Ln2O9–Ln1O8–Ln2O9 trimers (see Figure ), which are similar to those found in CaHPA and CdHPA derivatives.

elements.content: For both series, the 3D frameworks result from trimeric units interconnecting the layers. Large oval-shaped channels are formed by the spatial separation of the layers along the b-axis. The resulting open-framework structures enclose 1D channels running parallel to the c-axis, filled with lattice water molecules (see Figure b).

elements.content: Some structural variations are found in the Ln series when compared to the CaHPA trimer found in Ca3(HPA)2(H2O)14. For instance, the central Ln1 atom is 8-coordinated, whereas the central Ca atom in the CaHPA trimer is 6-coordinated. This higher coordination of Ln1 is likely the cause of a decrease in the Ln2–Ln1–Ln2 angle, with respect to that of Ca2–Ca1–Ca2, which was 180°. A more pronounced bending in the Ln–Ln–Ln angle is found for series I frameworks. Hence, the Ln2–Ln1–Ln2 angle varies from 142.7° (series II) to 126.4° (series I). These variations in Ln–Ln–Ln angles force the position of phosphonate group, P2, which connects Ln1 to Ln2. Hence, intratrimer P2···P2 distance is 7.26(2) Å and 4.41(2) Å for series II and series I, respectively. On the other hand, and on the basis of the presence of a chiral carbon center in the HPA ligand, the central lanthanide ion in the trimeric SBU shows a preference for the S isomer of P2, thus exerting chirality to the Ln1{P2}2 unit. This trend is maintained along the series. These chiral units are encapsulated between layers formed from a R and S racemic mixture of ligands.

A more pronounced bending in the Ln-Ln-Ln angle is found for series I frameworks. Hence, the Ln2-Ln1-Ln2 angle varies from 142.7° (series II) to 126.4° (series I). These variations in Ln-Ln-Ln angles force the position of phosphonate group, P2, which connects Ln1 to Ln2. Hence, intratrimer P2⋅⋅⋅P2 distance is 7.26(2) Å and 4.41(2) Å for series II and series I, respectively. This trend is maintained along the series. These chiral units are encapsulated between layers formed from a R and S racemic mixture of ligands.

elements.content: The water molecules occupying the 1D channels in the structure of GdHPA-II are found in a disordered arrangement and could not be positioned from single-crystal data. However, an attempt to localize the water molecules was carried out from powder diffraction data for TbHPA-II and CeHPA-I. The structural formula can be expanded as Ln3H(O3PCH(OH)COO)2(HO3PCH(OH)COO)2(H2O)8·8H2O, in order to highlight (a) the disordered nature of one proton and (b) the two types of water molecules: one coordinated to the lanthanide and the second filling the center of the channels (i.e., lattice water). For the two series, four crystallographically independent lattice water oxygens could be found which are grouped in two “types”: (i) two water molecules are located close to the wall of the channels, which are interacting strongly through hydrogen bonding with phosphonate and carboxylate groups; and (ii) two additional water molecules close to the center of the channels (see Figure b).

elements.content: Information about possible structural rearrangements upon water removal was revealed by analyzing the XRD patterns of the samples subjected to dehydration–rehydration cycles under vacuum at room temperature (Figure ). LaHPA-I progressively loses crystallinity, becoming amorphous after 4 h of treatment, with the final pressure reaching ∼2 × 10–4 mbar. This sample did not recover its crystallinity when exposed to air or under a humid atmosphere of saturated NaCl for 7 days. However, after moistening the sample (12 mg) with 3 drops of water and subsequent air-drying, the amorphous compound was converted to a crystalline material with series II crystal structure. Therefore, a complete cycle of water desorption under vacuum, followed by readsorption resulted in a change of symmetry from Iba2 to Pcan. Under the same conditions, series II materials displayed amorphization upon dehydration but subsequent rehydration led to the same type of structure (see Figure ). The necessity of a few drops of liquid water to ensure the rearrangement from phase I to phase II, via the amorphous phase, does not allow one to rule out recrystallization in the presence of liquid water.

elements.content: Structural evolution of both polymorphic forms, LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II, during the dehydration–rehydration processes under vacuum at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 7  Structural evolution of both polymorphic forms, LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II, during the dehydration-rehydration processes under vacuum at room temperature.

elements.content: The two polymorphic phases I and II can be distinguished by their slightly different thermal behaviors. As an example, TG-DTA curves for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II are shown in Figure . For both series, dehydration starts at 35–40 °C and it is completed at ∼180 °C, with most of the water content being removed below 140 °C. The heat flow curve reveals three overlapping steps of dehydration. The overall weight loss is shifted to higher temperature for LaHPA-II, suggesting a stronger H-bond interaction of water in this framework. This is consistent with the smaller unit cell volumes found for series II compounds. Similar dehydration patterns were observed for all compounds of each series.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior and Surface Characterization

The two polymorphic phases I and II can be distinguished by their slightly different thermal behaviors. As an example, TG-DTA curves for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II are shown in Figure . For both series, dehydration starts at 35-40 °C and it is completed at ~180 °C, with most of the water content being removed below 140 °C. The heat flow curve reveals three overlapping steps of dehydration. The overall weight loss is shifted to higher temperature for LaHPA-II, suggesting a stronger H-bond interaction of water in this framework. This is consistent with the smaller unit cell volumes found for series II compounds. Similar dehydration patterns were observed for all compounds of each series.

elements.content: TGA (solid lines) and DTA (dots) curves for LaHPA-I (blue) and LaHPA-II (red) polymorphic forms of La3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4·16H2O.
elements.clean_text: 8  TGA (solid lines) and DTA (dots) curves for LaHPA-I (blue) and LaHPA-II (red) polymorphic forms of La3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4⋅16H2O.

elements.content: For series I materials, lattice water is likely lost below 100 °C, since the weight loss percentage (10.5 wt %) closely matches the theoretical value for eight lattice water molecules (10.91 wt %), while the metal-bound water is lost between 100 °C and 200 °C. However, for series II materials, a clear separation between lattice and metal-bound water removal was indistinguishable. Unfortunately, no discernible plateau was detected between the loss of lattice water and the loss of water bound to the lanthanide cations. All attempts to prepare the materials as crystalline compounds without the lattice water (i.e., Ln3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4(H2O)8) were unsuccessful. Above 240 °C, thermal decomposition takes place. The total water content was also estimated from the weight loss up to 900 °C, assuming the thermal decomposition product to be composed of amorphous P2O5, together with crystalline LnPO4 (Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction File (PDF) Card No. 01-084-0600). The calculated water content ranged from 15 to 16 water molecules per formula, which is consistent with the elemental analyses and the crystallographic study.

elements.content: The dehydration processes for series I and II hybrids were also followed by thermodiffractometry under an open atmosphere (see ). In agreement with the thermal analysis, series II compounds exhibit a slightly higher thermal stability. GdHPA-II heated at 120 °C yielded a crystalline pattern (see ), with the amorphization starting at 130 °C. A sample of GdHPA-II was first heated at 150 °C and was subsequently partially rehydrated after moistening with water and air-drying, but no phase transition (II→I) was observed. Amorphization for LaHPA-I starts close to 80 °C and the sample heated at 100 °C yielded a quasi-amorphous pattern (see ); this temperature corresponds to the loss of half of the hydration waters, as monitored by thermal analysis. Again, the resulting rehydrated compound, following the procedure described above, has the typical pattern of series II compounds. This behavior suggests that series II, with smaller unit-cell volume, is the most stable polymorph for LnHPA hybrids.

elements.content: The textural properties for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II were studied by outgassing the samples under high vacuum at room temperature for several hours until a mass loss equivalent to the full removal of the lattice waters occurred. The N2 isotherms gave no porosity and only a low CO2 adsorption (isotherms not shown), with micropore surface areas of ∼85 m2 g–1, deduced from the Dubinin–Radushkevich equation.

elements.content: Selected spectra for CeHPA-I, PrHPA-I, GdHPA-II, and TbHPA-II, are given in . A followup of sample LaHPA-I, heated in situ at selected temperatures up to 190 °C, is also shown in . All LnHPA hybrids show similar FT-IR spectra and only small differences in the widths and intensities of the bands are observed. The broad O–H stretching region confirms the existence of several types of water molecules interacting through H-bonds with variable strength, from weak (∼3500 cm–1) to strong (∼ 3100 cm–1) interactions. Intense bands are observed close to 1585 cm–1 and 1440 cm–1, corresponding to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the carboxylate groups [O–C–O–], respectively. Remarkably, a band at ∼1695 cm–1, which has been highlighted in , becomes apparent upon heating sample LaHPA-I in situ, above 100 °C (). This band is likely due to the stretching vibration of carboxylic groups, and its presence suggests that the disordered proton upon heating is localized on the carboxylate groups. Other bands located in the 900–1200 cm–1 region are associated to the phosphonate moieties and they are found in similar metal carboxyphosphonate materials.

FT-IR Spectroscopy

Selected spectra for CeHPA-I, PrHPA-I, GdHPA-II, and TbHPA-II, are given in . A followup of sample LaHPA-I, heated in situ at selected temperatures up to 190 °C, is also shown in . All LnHPA hybrids show similar FT-IR spectra and only small differences in the widths and intensities of the bands are observed. The broad O-H stretching region confirms the existence of several types of water molecules interacting through H-bonds with variable strength, from weak (~3500 cm-1) to strong (~ 3100 cm-1) interactions. Intense bands are observed close to 1585 cm-1 and 1440 cm-1, corresponding to the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of the carboxylate groups [O-C-O-], respectively. Remarkably, a band at ~1695 cm-1, which has been highlighted in , becomes apparent upon heating sample LaHPA-I in situ, above 100 °C (). This band is likely due to the stretching vibration of carboxylic groups, and its presence suggests that the disordered proton upon heating is localized on the carboxylate groups. Other bands located in the 900-1200 cm-1 region are associated to the phosphonate moieties and they are found in similar metal carboxyphosphonate materials.

elements.content: The 31P NMR characteristic signal for the tetrahedral −CPO(OH)2 moiety of the phosphonic acids, appearing at 17–20 ppm, is shifted, upon metal coordination, to higher field and may be split if different coordination modes coexist. The 31P MAS NMR spectrum for LaHPA-II (Figure a) is simpler than that of LaHPA-I (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
MAS NMR Study

The 31P NMR characteristic signal for the tetrahedral -CPO(OH)2 moiety of the phosphonic acids, appearing at 17-20 ppm, is shifted, upon metal coordination, to higher field and may be split if different coordination modes coexist. The 31P MAS NMR spectrum for LaHPA-II (Figure a) is simpler than that of LaHPA-I (Figure b).

elements.content: 31P MAS NMR spectrum for (a) LaHPA-II and (b) LaHPA-I, showing the fitting for (b).
elements.clean_text: 9   31P MAS NMR spectrum for (a) LaHPA-II and (b) LaHPA-I, showing the fitting for (b).

elements.content: The former shows two isotropic resonances, at ∼14.5 ppm and ∼5.0 ppm. The appearance of two main signals in the NMR spectrum is consistent with the existence of two crystallographically independent phosphorus atoms, showing different metal–phosphonate connectivities and protonation degrees. Higher connectivity and, hence, lower protonation degree causes greater upfield shifts of the resonance. The fitting of the proton decoupling 31P MAS NMR bands using the program DMFIT gave a relative contribution −CPO3H–/–CPO3 2– = 1/1. These results combined with the crystallographic data are consistent with the proposed general formula Ln3H(O3PCH(OH)COO)2(HO3PCH(OH)COO)2·16H2O. On this basis, we tentatively assign the low-field (∼14 ppm) and the high-field (∼5 ppm) signals to P2 and P1, respectively. Figure b displays the 31P MAS NMR spectrum for LaHPA-I. The corresponding signals are split and that of P1 (∼7 ppm) is shifted to lower field by ∼2 ppm, when compared to the resonances of LaHPA-II. The split and shift P1 signal in LaHPA-I suggest the existence of slightly different environments and highly distorted phosphorus tetrahedra. The crystallographic study for LaHPA-I shows two average phosphorus positions and the proton disorder is likely the origin of the observed splitting of the phosphorus local environments.

elements.content: The 1H MAS NMR spectra for samples LaHPA-II and LaHPA-I are shown in Figures a and b, respectively. They consist of broad bands that can be deconvoluted into several components. For the LaHPA-II spectrum (see Figure a), two main signals are observed at 5.8 ppm (broad) and at 5.4 ppm (sharp), which are associated with metal-bound and lattice waters, respectively. For LaHPA-I (see Figure b), these resonances are located at ∼5.5 ppm (very broad) and ∼4.9 ppm (sharp). The resonances located at 8.4 ppm and 2.4 ppm are typical of the protons of hydrogen phosphonate (−CPO3H) and hydroxyl (−HCOH) groups, respectively. For LaHPA-I, these bands are situated at 8.6 ppm and 1.5 ppm, respectively. In addition, the spectrum for LaHPA-II (see Figure a) contains another resonance at 13.2 ppm that may be attributed to proton of the carboxylic group. This band is virtually absent in LaHPA-I, showing that the hydrogen disorder is different in the two series, which agrees with the 31P NMR data discussed above.

elements.content: Taking together the 1H and 31P NMR data, some information about the structurally nonlocalized proton, Ln3 H(O3PCH(OH)COO)2(HO3PCH(OH)COO)2·16H2O, may be inferred. The NMR results suggest that this proton may be preferentially associated to a carboxylate group in LaHPA-II, resonance at ∼13 ppm, and to one phosphonate group, ∼8 ppm, for LaHPA-I.

elements.content: Additional information was obtained by recording the 1H MAS NMR spectrum for LaHPA-I after heating (see Figure c). As expected, dehydration causes the intensity of the signal associated with the lattice water (sharp band at ∼5.5 ppm) to decrease abruptly. As a result, the relative contribution of the signal due to the lanthanum-bound water (very broad band at ∼6 ppm) increases notably. Very interestingly, the intensity of the resonance at 14.4 ppm increases in the partially dehydrated LaHPA-I which may be attributed to the proton of a −COOH group. Therefore, partial dehydration profoundly affects the position of the disordered proton which departs from the phosphonic and approaches the carboxylate group. This carboxylic resonance is very similar to that observed for LaHPA-II, as discussed above. The localization of the disordered hydrogens close to carboxylic group in the trimers, after partial LaHPA-I dehydration, may justify the conversion to LaHPA-II upon rehydration.

elements.content: The presence of 1D channels, filled with water molecules, in the crystal structures of both series (see Figure ), suggests the possibility of proton conductivity behavior. Furthermore, there are certain structural features that make these good candidates as proton-conductors at room temperature. These include the −POH groups pointing toward the interior of the channels, the network of hydrogen bonds within the channels and the proximity between the lattice water molecules. Therefore, conductivity studies have been carried out for one representative member of each series. Impedance spectra for GdHPA-II and LaHPA-I at different relative humidity (%RH) values and temperatures were collected, and they are shown in the .
elements.clean_text:
Proton-Conductivity Study

The presence of 1D channels, filled with water molecules, in the crystal structures of both series (see Figure ), suggests the possibility of proton conductivity behavior. Furthermore, there are certain structural features that make these good candidates as proton-conductors at room temperature. These include the -POH groups pointing toward the interior of the channels, the network of hydrogen bonds within the channels and the proximity between the lattice water molecules. Therefore, conductivity studies have been carried out for one representative member of each series. Impedance spectra for GdHPA-II and LaHPA-I at different relative humidity (%RH) values and temperatures were collected, and they are shown in the .

elements.content: When GdHPA-II is exposed to the highest %RH value of 98%, a spike is observed which has an associated capacitance of ∼1 μF. Since the spike is inclined to the Z′ axis by ∼70°, see , it indicates a partial-blocking electrode response that allows limited diffusion; therefore, the conducting species must be ionic (i.e., H+ ions). The total pellet resistance (R T) was obtained from the intercept of the spike and/or the arc (low frequency end) on the Z′ axis. At 98% RH and T = 21 °C, σT was 3.2 × 10–4 S cm–1. This value is larger than those values recently reported for some metal phosphonate MOF materialsσ ≈ (3.5–5) × 10–5 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 95–98% RH,but slightly lower than those reported by us for magnesium and lanthanum tetraphosphonates (σ = 1.6 × 10–3 S cm–1 and 8 × 10–3 S cm–1, respectively, measured under similar conditions). These last values are on the same order than that reported for (NH4)2(adp)[Zn2(ox)3]· 3H2O (adp = adipic acid), which shows the highest proton conductivity (σ ≈ 8 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 98% RH). When reducing the RH values, the overall conductivity values decrease, as expected for proton conductors (see ).

Since the spike is inclined to the Z' axis by ~70°, see , it indicates a partial-blocking electrode response that allows limited diffusion; therefore, the conducting species must be ionic (i.e., H+ ions). The total pellet resistance (R T) was obtained from the intercept of the spike and/or the arc (low frequency end) on the Z' axis. At 98% RH and T = 21 °C, σT was 3.2 × 10-4 S cm-1. This value is larger than those values recently reported for some metal phosphonate MOF materialsσ ~ (3.5-5) × 10-5 S cm-1 at 25 °C and 95-98% RH,but slightly lower than those reported by us for magnesium and lanthanum tetraphosphonates (σ = 1.6 × 10-3 S cm-1 and 8 × 10-3 S cm-1, respectively, measured under similar conditions). These last values are on the same order than that reported for (NH4)2(adp)[Zn2(ox)3]⋅ 3H2O (adp = adipic acid), which shows the highest proton conductivity (σ ~ 8 × 10-3 S cm-1 at 25 °C and 98% RH). When reducing the RH values, the overall conductivity values decrease, as expected for proton conductors (see ).

elements.content: Proton conductivity properties were also measured for LaHPA-I. The overall behavior was similar, but the conductivity values were ∼2 orders of magnitude lower than those of series II. LaHPA-I sample took much more time to equilibrate at a given water partial pressure. As an example, the proton conductivity (σT) for LaHPA-I was 5.6 × 10–6 S cm–1 at 98% RH and T = 21 °C. Selected conductivity plots are given in .

elements.content: The overall pellet conductivities for GdHPA-II, in traditional Arrhenius format, are given in Figure for two %RH values. The derived activation energies for the conduction process were 0.23 and 0.49 eV for 98% RH and 69% RH, respectively. These reported activation energies are located within the range typically attributed to a Grotthuss transfer mechanism via water molecules (0.1–0.4 eV). The increase in activation energy when decreasing the water partial pressure is very likely related to a decrease in the water content within the channels (see above). The overall pellet conductivities for LaHPA-I, in traditional Arrhenius format, are given in . The derived activation energies are similar and close to 0.20 eV.

elements.content: Initially, a steady-state luminescence study was undertaken. The emission spectra for LnHPA-II samples, with different loadings of Eu, after excitation at 370 nm and recorded at room temperature display the characteristic sharp lines assigned to transitions between the first excited nondegenerate 5D0 state and the 7F0–4 levels of the fundamental septet (see Figure ). Similar spectrum profiles have been obtained for the studied samples, Eu0.95Tb0.05HPA, Eu0.9Tb0.1HPA, and Gd0.95Eu0.05HPA, but with different emission intensities (see Figure ).

Photoluminescence Characterization

Initially, a steady-state luminescence study was undertaken. The emission spectra for LnHPA-II samples, with different loadings of Eu, after excitation at 370 nm and recorded at room temperature display the characteristic sharp lines assigned to transitions between the first excited nondegenerate 5D0 state and the 7F0-4 levels of the fundamental septet (see Figure ). Similar spectrum profiles have been obtained for the studied samples, Eu0.95Tb0.05HPA, Eu0.9Tb0.1HPA, and Gd0.95Eu0.05HPA, but with different emission intensities (see Figure ).

elements.clean_text: 12  Room-temperature emission spectra for Eu-containing derivatives of series II: (a) EuHPA-II, (b) Eu0.9Tb0.1HPA, (c) Eu0.95Tb0.05HPA, and (d) Gd0.95Eu0.05HPA. The excitation wavelength was 370 nm.

elements.content: In order to understand the role of the water coordination in the structure, EuHPA-II was dehydrated at 110 °C for 60 min observing a blue shift of 5 nm for the transition 5D0→7F2 (see Figure ). This blue shift can be assigned to the modification of the coordination sphere around the Eu3+ centers. The presence of a shoulder at 612 nm in the dehydrated sample suggests that still some water remains around Eu centers. The reversibility of the dehydration–rehydration process for the partly dehydrated EuHPA-II was studied by exposing this sample to a water-saturated atmosphere. Then, the emission spectra were taken upon different times of exposure to the moisture. The characteristic emission bands show a reversible behavior with an isosbestic point located at 615 nm.

elements.content: Second, luminescence lifetime measurements were carried out. Lifetime values were obtained by monitoring the temporal profile of the 5D0→7F2 transition. The decay curves monitored at 618 nm can be fitted as a monoexponential curve. At room temperature, all the samples show similar behavior with a lifetime decay of ∼262 μs (see ). The sample Gd0.95Eu0.05HPA shows slightly slower signal decay, probably due to lower contribution of nonraditative paths to 5D0 depopulation as Eu–Eu pairs become less probable.

elements.content: The reversibility of the dehydration process was studied in detail by considering the temporal profiles of the dehydrated EuHPA-II sample and subsequently exposed to moisture. After EuHPA-II was dehydrated at 110 °C for 60 min, its signal lifetime increases from 262 μs in the original sample to 417 μs in the partly dehydrated material. The reversible behavior was proven when the sample was exposed to a saturated water atmosphere. The lifetime decreases with the exposition time to moisture (see Figure ). It may be possible to estimate the number of Eu-bound water molecules by the previously reported formula: n = 1.05 × τ H 2 O − 1 − 0.70

elements.content: The inset of Figure gives a table with the 5D0 lifetime and the average calculated number of water molecules coordinated to Eu emission centers. It can be seen that the calculated number of Eu-bound water molecules (3.31), from this very simple approach, is not far from the average value expected from the structural determination (2.67). This value is the multiplicity-averaged value of Eu1(H2O)4 and Eu2(H2O)2, with Eu1 having half multiplicity than Eu2. Upon heating, EuHPA-II loses ∼1.5 water molecules per Eu site upon dehydration at 110 °C. Then, the number of Eu-coordinated water molecules increases as the exposure time to atmospheric moisture increases, but the fully hydrated EuHPA sample is not recovered after exposure to water moisture for 120 min.

elements.content: Finally, the behavior of the water with temperature for open-framework EuHPA-II derived from the luminescence study is fully consistent with the TGA-DTA and thermodiffractometric studies. In the investigated experimental conditions, it was not possible to isolate the water-evacuated channels without removing water from the lanthanum first-coordination sphere. The removal of water molecules linked to Ln sites provokes the amorphization of this open-framework structure, and then no adsorption capacity is observed in the fully dehydrated EuHPA-II sample.

elements.content:
Recently, intense efforts are devoted to produce lanthanide MOF materials exhibiting unique cooperative multifunctionality. Phosphonate-based MOFs are at the epicenter of a field that is far from ripe, presenting a multitude of opportunities and challenges. Within this general framework, here, we have reported a full new family of Ln-based 3D MOFs (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, and Dy) with the ligand 2-hydroxyphosphonoacetate. The principal conclusions can be summarized as follows:

Compounds LnHPA, with the formula Ln3(H0.75O3PCHOHCOO)4·xH2O (x = 15–16) crystallize in the orthorhombic system. Two types of structures can be isolated: series I and II polymorphs. Series I compounds crystallize in a noncentrosymmetric structure (e.g., Iba2), whereas series II samples crystallize in a centrosymmetric structure (e.g., Pcan).

Synthesis pH plays a significant role on the identity of the products. For example, for the La derivative, the polymorphic phase LaHPA-I was obtained for pH values of <0.8, whereas LaHPA-II was prepared at pH values of >1.0. Syntheses at intermediate pH values led to a mixture of these phases.

For both series I and II polymorphs, the 3D frameworks result from the linkage of organic–inorganic layers by central lanthanide cations, which yield trimeric SBUs also found in several other metal–HPA hybrids. Large oval-shaped 1D channels, running along the c-axis, are formed by the spatial separation of the layers and filled with lattice water molecules.

LnHPA compounds show crystalline-to-amorphous-to-crystalline transformations, upon dehydration–rehydration processes.

LnHPA materials also show proton conductivity. For example, for LaHPA (series I), σT = 5.6 × 10–6 S cm–1 and for GdHPA (series II), σT = 3.2 × 10–4 S cm–1, both at 98% RH and T = 21 °C.

Photoluminescence results, including lifetime measurements, indicate that the dehydration–rehydration of emitting Eu centers is reversible. The Eu-bound water content can be estimated by a simple approach from the luminescence lifetimes.

cln_elements.content: For the syntheses in gels, the following stock solutions were prepared. By using the concentrated H3HPA starting solution, a more-dilute 0.133 M stock solution was made. Fifteen milliliters (15 mL) of this solution contains 0.3 mmol of H3HPA. Using the solid lanthanide nitrates, 0.1 M stock solutions were prepared in DI water. In a glass beaker, 1 g of sodium alginate was dissolved in ∼100 mL of DI water, thus generating a 1% w/v solution. Four milliliters (4 mL) of the above alginate stock solution are transferred into 25-mL glass vials. Then, with a Pasteur pipet, 2 mL (0.2 mmol) of the above lanthanide stock solutions were added. Upon addition of the lanthanide solution, immediate gel formation was observed. The forming gel was left undisturbed for at least 9 h to ensure maximum exchange of Ln3+ ions for Na+ ions. Subsequently, the excess liquid was decanted, the gel was washed several times with DI water, and was then ready for the next step.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Lanthanide-HPA Materials

Synthesis of Lanthanide-Containing Alginate Gels

For the syntheses in gels, the following stock solutions were prepared. By using the concentrated H3HPA starting solution, a more-dilute 0.133 M stock solution was made. Fifteen milliliters (15 mL) of this solution contains 0.3 mmol of H3HPA. Using the solid lanthanide nitrates, 0.1 M stock solutions were prepared in DI water. In a glass beaker, 1 g of sodium alginate was dissolved in ~100 mL of DI water, thus generating a 1% w/v solution. Four milliliters (4 mL) of the above alginate stock solution are transferred into 25-mL glass vials. Then, with a Pasteur pipet, 2 mL (0.2 mmol) of the above lanthanide stock solutions were added. Upon addition of the lanthanide solution, immediate gel formation was observed. The forming gel was left undisturbed for at least 9 h to ensure maximum exchange of Ln3+ ions for Na+ ions. Subsequently, the excess liquid was decanted, the gel was washed several times with DI water, and was then ready for the next step.

cln_elements.content:
The two polymorphic phases I and II can be distinguished by their slightly different thermal behaviors. As an example, TG-DTA curves for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II are shown in Figure . For both series, dehydration starts at 35–40 °C and it is completed at ∼180 °C, with most of the water content being removed below 140 °C. The heat flow curve reveals three overlapping steps of dehydration. The overall weight loss is shifted to higher temperature for LaHPA-II, suggesting a stronger H-bond interaction of water in this framework. This is consistent with the smaller unit cell volumes found for series II compounds. Similar dehydration patterns were observed for all compounds of each series.

The textural properties for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II were studied by outgassing the samples under high vacuum at room temperature for several hours until a mass loss equivalent to the full removal of the lattice waters occurred. The N2 isotherms gave no porosity and only a low CO2 adsorption (isotherms not shown), with micropore surface areas of ∼85 m2 g–1, deduced from the Dubinin–Radushkevich equation.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior and Surface Characterization

The two polymorphic phases I and II can be distinguished by their slightly different thermal behaviors. As an example, TG-DTA curves for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II are shown in Figure . For both series, dehydration starts at 35-40 °C and it is completed at ~180 °C, with most of the water content being removed below 140 °C. The heat flow curve reveals three overlapping steps of dehydration. The overall weight loss is shifted to higher temperature for LaHPA-II, suggesting a stronger H-bond interaction of water in this framework. This is consistent with the smaller unit cell volumes found for series II compounds. Similar dehydration patterns were observed for all compounds of each series.

The textural properties for LaHPA-I and LaHPA-II were studied by outgassing the samples under high vacuum at room temperature for several hours until a mass loss equivalent to the full removal of the lattice waters occurred. The N2 isotherms gave no porosity and only a low CO2 adsorption (isotherms not shown), with micropore surface areas of ~85 m2 g-1, deduced from the Dubinin-Radushkevich equation.
